problems.question: A small cleaning robot accelerates at 2.5 \(\text{ms}^{-2}\) when a motor provides a forward force of 25 N. What is the mass of the robot?
problems.author: Filip Kilibarda

problems.question: While practicing in the pool, a swimmer pushes water directly backwards with a force of 40 N. According to Newton’s third law, what force does the water exert on the swimmer? Give magnitude and direction.
problems.hint: Newton’s third law: every action has an equal and opposite reaction.
problems.detailed: The swimmer pushes water backward with 40 N. The water pushes the swimmer forward with an equal 40 N. Hence the answer is 40 N forward.
problems.author: Filip Kilibarda

problems.question: An observer is looking at a man at a bus station. The man is accelerating at 1 \(\text{ms}^{-2}\), but the observer says he (the observer) feels 0 N. Which statement best explains this?
options: The observer is not the one accelerating, so the observer feels no net force (0 N).
The man has zero mass, so there is no force on either of them.
If acceleration is small (1 \(\text{ms}^{-2}\)) the force is negligible and counted as 0 N.
Newton’s second law only applies to objects in free fall, so it does not apply here.
problems.hint: Forces act on the object that is accelerating, not on someone watching it.
problems.detailed: The observer is not accelerating. According to Newton’s second law, \(F = ma\). Since \(a = 0\) for the observer, \(F = 0\).
problems.author: Filip Kilibarda

problems.question: A 20 N force is applied horizontally to push a 4 kg box on a frictionless surface. What is the acceleration of the box?
problems.hint: Apply Newton’s second law: \(F = ma \implies a = \frac{F}{m}\).
problems.author: Filip Kilibarda

problems.question: A 67 kg man stands on a scale inside an elevator that is accelerating upward at 2.0 \(\text{ms}^{-2}\). What reading (apparent weight, in newtons) will the scale show? (Use \(g = 9.8\, \text{ms}^{-2}\))
problems.hint: The scale shows the normal force, which equals \(mg + ma\) if the elevator accelerates upward.
problems.author: Filip Kilibarda
